title: How to Paint a Watercolor Wash

steps.headline: Stretch your watercolor paper.
steps.description: When painting watercolor washes, you need to prepare the paper. Soak a sheet of watercolor paper in cold water for 2 minutes. Remove the paper from the water and place it on a flat drawing board. Smooth the paper out with a sponge. Watercolor wash techniques won't work if the paper is too wet. Tape the paper around all the edges firmly to the board, and let it dry.

steps.headline: Select a large watercolor brush that holds plenty of paint and covers a large area.
steps.description: When painting watercolor washes, you need to cover the entire paper.

steps.headline: Choose the background color you want and put a large amount on your palette.
steps.description: To paint with watercolors, you'll need to add enough water to obtain your desired hue.

steps.headline: Draw a large square lightly on the paper with a pencil.
steps.description: This may help you learn control with watercolor wash techniques.

steps.headline: Dampen your paper by dipping your brush in water and lightly sweeping it across the paper.
Dunk your brush in the watercolor paint you prepared.
steps.description: When painting watercolor washes, start at the top of the page with a broad, horizontal stroke to the other side. Practice keeping the brushstrokes even and within the square.

steps.headline: Load your brush with more paint and then move down the paper, 1 brush line at a time.
steps.description: When you paint with watercolors, you may overlap the previous stroke. When you reach the bottom, let the paper dry.

steps.headline: Dip your brush in the prepared paint.
steps.description: The graded wash is a watercolor wash technique that produces a background with varying monotone hues.

steps.headline: Apply the paint with 1 brush stroke across the top of the square.
steps.description: Continue going down until you fill the entire square.

steps.headline: Add water to each brush stroke to lighten the color, or put in more pigment to darken the hue.
steps.description: To paint with watercolors, you need to learn how to create different contrasts with 1 color.

steps.headline: Wet the entire paper by dipping your brush in water and lightly stroking it across the page.
Select the colors you desire for a blended wash. With watercolor wash techniques, you could try red and orange to depict a sunset.
Immerse your brush in one color, and then drag it back and forth across the paper.
steps.description: Add a new color without cleaning your brush. This will create a soft transition between the hues when painting watercolor washes.

steps.headline: Spread different amounts of pigment and water to the wet paper to create a pattern or design.
